item.title: Cleveland FBI stops potential Fourth of July terror attack --- HOLD
item.dc:creator: jbuffa
item.content:encoded:
An undercover Cleveland F.B.I. [official website] agent charged [complaint, PDF] Demetrius Pitts, who was planning multiple terror attacks to take place on the Fourth of July. Mr. Pitts, known by multiple different names, was arrested for attempting to provide material support or resources to a foreign terror organization. The F.B.I. had been investigating Pitts since December 2015, for threats made against the United States on social media. Special Agent Andrew Wilson was in charge of this case, and met multiple times with Pitts while undercover. He discovered Pitts' loyalty to al-Qaeda and disdain for American military members. Pitts wanted to make military families suffer as he believed the United States military caused suffering in the Middle East.
Pitts also suggested to the UCE [undercover agent] that these remote control cars packed with explosives be given to the children of military personnel to play with at the parade, so that the children would unwittingly detonate the bombs.
Pitts has an extensive criminal record and was arrested during one of his meetings with the undercover agent.

item.title: Progressive Candidate sweeps Mexico Presidential election --- HOLD
item.dc:creator: jbuffa
item.content:encoded: Andrés Manuel López Obrador [official website], known as Amlo, has won the 2018 general election for the Mexican presidency.  In a sweeping victory [results tally], Amlo promised dramatic change for Mexico. He insists that he will lower his salary to promote a higher salary to those below him on the governmental chain, as well as increasing scholarship opportunities and implementing new social programs. The president-elect has also said that he does not agree with President Donald Trump's [official website] policies on immigration, but has stated: "We are never going to disrespect the U.S. Government, because we want them to respect us." This is his third time running for president. Previously, he served as the mayor of Mexico City. Andrés Manuel López Obrador takes office December 1st, 2018, in accordance with the Mexican Constitution.

item.title: UN Chief calls for support for Rohingya and lauds Bangladesh for aid---HOLD
item.dc:creator: srohtla
item.content:encoded: Secretary-General of the United Nations [website], Antonio Guterres, visited [United Nations News Report] Cox's Bazar in Bangladesh to support the Rohingya living in refugee camps in the region. Guterres lauded the government of Bangladesh and its people for accepting the refugees and providing them aid. He also called for an international effort to increase support for the Rohingya and for those aiding them in Bangladesh. Traveling with the United Nations (UN) head was Jim Yong Kim [profile], the World Bank Group President [organization website], who declared almost $500 million would be granted to help Bangladesh continue to aid the refugees. These calls for support come after a recent push [JURIST Report] by a UN Special Rapporteur to have the International Criminal Court investigate human rights abuses against the Rohingya community. Earlier in June, UN officials signed an agreement [JURIST Report] with the government of Myanmar that could help the Rohingya return, but the Rohingya face continuing challenges as they have still not been granted any rights of citizenship. Guterres maintained that the "UN will continue to insist on the voluntary 'right of return' of the Rohingya to their homes in Myanmar, but 'only when the conditions are there for them to live in full dignity.' ”

item.title: Judge blocks order to set former Brazilian president free---HOLD
item.dc:creator: bzeller
item.content:encoded: On Sunday, Brazilian Judge Sergio Moro blocked an appeals court judge's order to release former President Luiz Inacio Lula de Silva from jail. Judge Moro said the appeals court lacked authority to issue an order to free the former president. This order was backed by another appeals court judge, Judge Joao Pedro Gebran Neto, who ordered Lula to remain in prison and expressly forbid the police from attempting to set Lula free. This is the latest development in the case [JURIST] of former President of Brazil Luiz Inacio Lula de Silva. He was convicted of bribery in July 2017 and has had his sentence extended by the court of appeals to 12 years in jail. Despite his conviction, supporters of Lula hope to see him released in time for the presidential election in October.

item.title: A pharmaceutical company granted a temporarily injunction blocking use of its drug in a lethal injection---DNP
item.dc:creator: atomlinson
item.content:encoded: Judge Elizabeth Gonzalez of Clark County Eighth Judicial District Court [official website] on Wednesday granted Alvogen Inc. [official website] an injunction temporarily blocking the Nevada Corrections Department from utilizing Alvogen's sedative midazolam in an untested three-drug execution protocol, after allegations it obtained the drug illegally. As a result, death-row inmate Scott Dozier was granted a stay of execution on Wednesday by Judge Jennifer Togliatti of Clark County Eighth Judicial District Court for an execution scheduled to take place later that day. Alvogen brought the lawsuit arguing that use of its product to execute capital punishment would cause their reputation "irreparable injury". In addition, the company argues that midazolam is not fit for executions, citing the use of the drug in other states has been met with outcry that prisoners are subjected to cruel and unusual punishment from botched executions. Sandoz [official website], a pharamceutical company whose drug cisatracurium is to be used in three-drug cocktail also opposed use of its drug during the hearing on Wednesday. This is not the first execution halted by a challenge to a lethal injection [JURIST news archive] procedure. A hearing on the use of the drug in Nevada executions is scheduled to take place on September 10.

item.title: The European Court of Human Rights: a riot, a murder, and a victory---HOLD
item.dc:creator: chsu
item.content:encoded: The European Court of Human Rights ruled that Russia violated the rights of three members of its activist punk rock band known as the Pussy Riots. The Court comprised of seven judges and one section registrar. Most of the Court's decisions regarding individual complaints were made unanimously with the exception of two where one judge dissented from the majority. Russian authorities arrested Pussy riot members, Mariya Alekhina, Nadezhda Tolokonnikova, and Yekaterina Samutsevich following the bands impromptu performance on the Cathedral of Christ the Savior's apse in Moscow on February 21, 2012. The band was attempting to play one of its songs titled "Punk Prayer – Virgin Mary, Drive Putin Away”. The motive of the performance was to protest the current Russian political climate as well as the Moscow Patriarch Kirill. Alekhina, Tolokonnikova, and Samutsevich were charged with "hooliganism motivated by religious hatred". Subsequently, the three members were held in pre-trial custody for five months before a Russian trial court convicted them. The members were transported to and from court in a cramped vehicle. During trial the members were held in a glass box constantly surrounded by guards and a guard dog. The box they were held in offered only a small access door one meter from the ground from which they communicated with their attorneys without adequate privacy. Relying on third party linguistic experts to review the band's content, the court deemed the band's use of hand gestures and obscene language coupled with bright colored clothing and baclavas as offensive and insulting. Labelling the band's media as "extremist", the Russian trial court banned all Pussy Riot material from Russian media outlets. Alekhina, Tolokonnikova, and Samutsevich were sentenced to two years in prison. Alekhina, Tolokonnikova, and Samutsevich lodged a complaint[ECHR, complaint] with the European Court of Human Rights on June 19, 2012. They alleged violations under Articles 3, 5 § 3, 6, and 10 under the European Convention on Human Rights[text]. The applicants alleged that the cramped conditions in which they were transported between jail to trial and being kept in a glass cage under heavy  security throughout the trial violated Article 3 of the European Convention on Human Rights. The band alleged violations under Article 5 §3 due to being held for extended periods of time by Russian authorities. The band members alleged violation under Article 6 because it was difficult to effectively communicate with their attorneys while being held in a glass box, and the members were not able to challenge the testimony provided by investigators. Lastly, the members challenged their arrest in reaction to their church performance, along with the Russian court's banning of its media, a violation of freedom of expression under Article 10. In its decision[ECHR, decision], the European Court of Human Rights voted 6-1, holding there was a violation of the band members' rights under Article 3. The court unanimously held that there was a violation under Article 5 §3. The Court unanimously held there was violation under Article 6 §§ 1 and 3 (c), but stated there was no need to examine violations under Article 6 §§ 1 and 3 (d).  In a 6-1 vote, the Court held there was a violation of the band members' right to freedom of expression under Article 10 as a result of their arrest. Finally, in a unanimous holding, the Court ruled the Russian government's banning of Pussy Riot's media online is a violation of Article 10. The Court ordered 16,000 EUR in damages to  each to Alekhina and Tolokonnikova, and 5,000 EUR to Samutsevich. The Court also awarded 11,760 EUR in court costs and fees. On the same day, the ECHR held [decision, ECHR] that Russian authorities failed to expeditiously and competently investigate the murder of Moscow-based investigative reporter, Anna Politkovskaya. Politkovskaya was known for criticizing the Putin administration as well as the handling of rebellion in Chechnya. Politkovskaya was murdered in her apartment building on October 7, 2006. Politkovskaya's murder occurred suspiciously on then president Vladimir Putin's birthday. This led critics to suspect either the Russian government or the Chechnya Administration was behind the murder.   Alleging violation of right to life under Article 2 of the European Convention for Human Rights, Politkovskaya's surviving family members lodged complaint [complaint, ECHR] with the ECHR in 2007. The Court found that the Russian government delayed its investigative proceedings of Politkovskaya's murder without providing ample explanation to the public. It also found Russia's conclusion tracing the murder to a now deceased Russian national based in London as inadequate. By a 5-2 decision, the ECHR held that Russia violated Article 2 of the Convention and awarded 20,000 EUR in damages to the Politkovskaya's family.

item.title: Federal judge throws out lawsuit filed by the City of New York against multiple energy companies---HOLD
item.dc:creator: chsu
item.content:encoded: Today, a judge in the United States District Court [official website] for the Southern District of New York dismissed [case] a lawsuit filed by the City of New York against five oil companies. The City of New York sued British Petroleum, Chevron, ConocoPhillips, Exxon Mobil, Shell for collectively being responsible for the negative effects of greenhouse gas emissions that is affecting New York City. The city, having extensive coastal exposure and island landmass, has had to incur heavy costs to pay for city projects such as walls and levies due to rising sea levels and heavier storms. It alleged the companies' sale of oil and natural gas has contributed to its expenditures, and sought damages from the energy companies. The US-based defendants, Chevron, Exxon Mobil, and ConocoPhillips filed a motion to dismiss this lawsuit which was granted today by Judge F. Keenan. Noting that the federal government already has the Clean Air Act [reference, EPA] in place with provisions for enforcement, the judge reasoned this matter should be left to the executive and legislative branches, rather than a judicial one. The judge also noted the lawsuit includes two non-U.S. companies, then held that domestic lawsuits involving foreign parties should be approached with caution so as to not potentially damage foreign relations. Ultimately,by recognizing that carbon emissions has both national and global consequences, the judge stated that addressing the negative effects of carbon emissions on both fronts require involvement of respective legislatures and international law making bodies. A domestic judicial body should not unilaterally extend its arm into such matters.

item.title: Los Angeles City Attorney files injunction against Department of Justice---HOLD
item.dc:creator: jbuffa
item.content:encoded:
Los Angeles City Attorney, Mike Feuer filed an injunction in federal court, against the Department of Justice [official website] alleging that conditions imposed on city funding are unconstitutional. In July 2017, President Trump issued an executive order requiring all districts that receive the Edward Byrne Memorial Justice Assistance Grant (Byrne JAG) [official website], federal funding supporting local law enforcement, must follow new conditions regarding immigration.  Los Angeles uses this grant to help with anti-gang efforts. In a statement [official website], Feuer depicts how he is trying to keep his city safe.
We’re continuing to do everything in our power to stop the Trump administration from unconstitutionally tying federal civil immigration enforcement to the funding of L.A.’s anti-gang efforts...We won’t let the Trump Administration hold federal grant funding hostage to further its immigration policy prerogatives at the expense of protecting L.A.’s most vulnerable neighborhoods.
The City Attorney believes he has the grounds for this case due to a precedent set by Los Angeles v. Sessions [ruling, PDF], which ruled earlier this year that immigration related conditions on another federal grant to be unlawful.

item.title: Federal judge rules anti-abortion protesters can continue demonstrations at clinic---HOLD
item.dc:creator: lmoffutt
item.content:encoded:
A judge for the US District Court for the Eastern District of New York [official website] ruled [text, PDF] Friday that anti-abortion protesters may continue Saturday morning demonstrations in front of Choice Women's Medical Center [official website], saying the protesters and demonstrations outside the abortion clinic do not violate the Freedom of Access to Clinic Entrances Act (FACE) [text, HTML] or the New York State Clinic Access Act (NYSCAA). The New York State Office of Attorney General (OAG) filed the lawsuit in 2017 against thirteen protesters alleging that they violated FACE and NYSCAA, which prohibit persons from using force, threat of force or physical obstruction to prevent persons form providing or receiving reproductive health services.. This case arose from a complaint against the weekly demonstrations, which have taken place since 2012, outside of the Choice Women's Reproductive Health Center in Queens, New York. According to the Court's opinion, the anti-abortion protesters would "set up along the sidewalk leading to the Clinic entrance and proceed to engage in a variety of activities. Some hold large signs that purport to show images of aborted fetuses; others principally preach; still others attempt to hand approaching patients and their companions anti-abortion literature and to engage them in conversation about the morality of their actions." The Court reasoned in its opinion that:
The interactions on the sidewalk outside Choices were generally quite short, and there is no credible evidence that any protester disregarded repeated requests to be left alone over an extended period or changed his or her tone or message in response to requests to be left alone in a way that suggested an intent to harass, annoy, or alarm. The OAG has failed to show that any defendant had the intent to harass, annoy, or alarm a patient, companion, or escort.
The Court also cautioned the protesters to refrain from engaging in more aggressive conduct.

item.title: United Nations Human Rights Council votes to ascertain alleged human rights abuses in Gaza---HOLD
item.dc:creator: chsu
item.content:encoded: Today, the United Nations Human Rights Council announced [press release, UNHRC] the formation of aa three-personned Commission of Inquiry. The commission comprises of three experts charged with "[making] recommendations, in particular on accountability measures, all with a view to avoiding and ending impunity and ensuring legal accountability, including individual criminal and command responsibility, for such violations and abuses, and on protecting civilians against any further assaults”. The experts will lend their legal expertise in human rights to the situation on the ground. The commission officials comprise of lawyers and legal experts from North America, South Asia, and Sub-Saharan Africa. Professor David M. Crane of the United States will serve as chair of the commission.  The Commission is expected to present an oral update report during the UNHRC's 39th session in September 2018, and to produce a final report during its 40th session in March 2019. Since March 2018, there have been multiple violent incidents [article, JURIST] between Palestinian protesters and Israeli military in Gaza. In response, the UNHRC dispatched [article, JURIST] an independent commission to investigate the situation. The Human Rights Council also passed Resolution S-28/1 [resolution, UNHRC] on May 22, 2018, criticizing Israel's failure to impartially investigate allegations of human rights abuses; impartially adjudicate violent incidents; and the targeting of civilians. The resolution stressed the right to life and the right to peaceful assembly in accordance with international law, and called upon Israel to cease its activities and cooperate with UN investigators.

item.title: UK Supreme Court dismisses a petition for divorce based on older marriage statute---HOLD
item.dc:creator: chsu
item.content:encoded: On Wednesday, the Supreme Court of the United Kingdom dismissed [judgement, UK Supreme Court] a petition for divorce. The original petition was brought before the Central Family Court in London [official website] by a Mrs. Owens pursuant to Section 1(2)(b) of the Matrimonial Causes Act of 1973 [text]. The family court dismissed the petition. Mrs. Owens subsequently appealed the decision to Court of Appeal, where the case was also dismissed. Section 1(2)(b) of the Matrimonial Causes Act of 1973 provides that marriage has irretriveably broken down if "the respondent has behaved in such a way that the petitioner cannot reasonably be expected to live with the respondent".  In its analysis, the Supreme Court noted Mrs. Owens had an affair between 2012 and 2013, which Mr. Owens subsequently became aware of.  The Court noted Mrs. Owens alleged 27 incidents beginning in 2013 when Mr. Owens was argumentative and demeaning towards her. The Court also noted Mrs. Owens only relied on incidents after 2013, and not of any during the first 35 years of their marriage. The Supreme Court noted that divorce petitions in the UK and Wales are rarely challenged, and that courts rarely stand in the way to impede the realization of such petitions. Yet here, Mr. Owens did challenge the petition and the majority of the 27 claims made by Mrs. Owens. Because the petitioner filed her petition under Section 1(2)(b) of the Matrimonial Causes Act of 1973, the Supreme Court's concern was with the interpretation of Section 1(2)(b), and wished to set precedence. The Court held that the circumstances surrounding the petition did not amount to that which the petitioner could not reasonably be expected to continue living with the respondent; therefore the petition cannot be sustained under Section 1(2)(b).

item.title: UNICEF Director criticisms attacks against civilian facilities and services---HOLD
item.dc:creator: chsu
item.content:encoded: “Attacks against civilian facilities and services are unacceptable, inhumane and in breach of the basic laws of war," said [statement, UNICEF] Henrietta Fore, Executive Director of the United Nations Children's Fund [official site] (UNICEF). In a statement released by UNICEF Wednesday, Director Fore stated her agency had received reports of airstrikes damaging UNICEF aid facilities in Yemen. Warehouses containing hygiene and water supplies, fuel tanks, and a water-sanitation facility were damaged. Those facilities were essential to UNICEF's mission to combat Cholera and acute diarrhea. Fore stated lack of access to such facilities, services, and supplies exacerbate the poor state of public health in a region ravaged by war. UNICEF emphasizes the the toll war takes upon children, robbing them of their right to life, opportunities to lead healthy emotional lives, education, and to obtain gainful livelihoods.

item.title: Zimbabwe opposition activist denied asylum---HOLD
item.dc:creator: elowman
item.content:encoded: The Zambian government denied Zimbabwean opposition activist and former finance minister Tendai Biti asylum on Wednesday, which led to him being returned to his home country of Zambia.  Upon his return, Biti was charged [Washington Post report] with "inciting public violence" and "declaring unofficial election results" the following day.  The Zambian government returned [UN press release] Biti even though a Zambian court order had permitted him to seek asylum. The US Department of State [official website] said [statement; Twitter] the department was "gravely concerned" over the treatment of opposition activists in Zimbabwe and expressed disappointment in Zambia for returning Biti. The UN Refugee Agency [official website] also condemned Zambia.  "Refoulement or forcibly returning refugees and asylum-seekers to their country of origin is a serious violation of international refugee law," said an agency press release. "UNHCR calls on Zambia to investigate this reported incident urgently."   According to the Washington Post, Biti could be facing over ten years in prison. On Tuesday Human Rights Watch reported [JURIST report] that Zimbabwean government forces beat dozens of protesters.   In June a Zimbabwean court ruled [JURIST report] that citizens abroad cannot vote in the upcoming election.  In November Zimbabwe's high court ruled [JURIST report] that the country's military takeover was constitutional.

item.title: Mozambique imposes heavy accreditation fines on journalists---HOLD
item.dc:creator: zuram
item.content:encoded:
On Thursday, August 23rd, the Mozambican government will impose accreditation fees on local and foreign journalists. [Decree, PDF] The Committee to Protect Journalists criticized the move by the Mozambican government pointing out that there are upcoming local and national elections in Mozambique as well as new natural gas deals. Accreditation for foreign correspondents will cost around $8,640.
"Not only do these fee increases by the Mozambican government make it practically impossible for independent press to continue working, they also lay bare a flagrant attempt to undermine transparency ahead of elections and as the country brokers natural resource deals," Angela Quintal, CPJ's Africa program coordinator. [CPJ, Report]
The Mozambique national elections are set for October 2019. Mozambique is set to go ahead with a large LNG project in October. [Reuters, Report]

item.title: Federal appeals court rules government readings of smart meter data do not require warrants---HOLD
item.dc:creator: zuram
item.content:encoded:
On August 16th, the 7th Circuit ruled that government readings of smart meter data are considered searches that can be performed without warrants. [Opinion, PL] The Court listed the benefits associated with using smart meters that are not related to law enforcement as outweighing the intrusion to privacy, noting:
With these benefits stacked together, the government’s interest in smart meters is significant. Smart meters allow utilities to reduce costs, provide cheaper power to consumers, encourage energy efficiency, and increase grid stability. We hold that these interests render the city’s search reasonable, where the search is unrelated to law enforcement, is minimally invasive, and presents little risk of corollary criminal consequences.
Additionally, the Court pointed out that the local government could have avoided controversy by having its residents agree to have the smart meters installed.

item.title: U.S. judge rejects executive orders that made it easier to fire federal employees ---HOLD
item.dc:creator: rmoore
item.content:encoded:
A federal judge on Saturday invalidated [pdf, opinion] important elements of three executive orders President Donald Trump signed in May. This ruling follows a June lawsuit, filed by 13 federal employee unions, challenging the legality of the executive orders' provisions. The executive orders aimed [The Hill report] to make it easier for agencies to fire federal employees with poor work performance by reducing the amount of time workers have to improve their performance. They would have also provided [Reuters report] more favorable union deals to agencies and would have made it a requirement for federal employees in unions to devote less time to union responsibilities. According to the Trump administration, this would have saved taxpayers millions of dollars and reduced government bureaucracy. However, U.S. District Court Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson [official profile] said that the orders overstepped the boundaries of the president's power. She wrote:
This Court has concluded that, although the President has the authority to issue executive orders in the realm of federal labor relations, many of the challenged provisions of the Orders at issue here effectively reduce the scope of the right to bargain collectively as Congress has crafted it, or impair the ability of agency officials to bargain in good faith as Congress has directed, and therefore cannot be sustained.
The White House has not responded to Jackson's decision.

item.title: ICC prosecutor calls for conviction of former Congo military leader---HOLD
item.dc:creator: arundell
item.content:encoded:
During closing statements [Reuters report] on Tuesday, the Prosecutor of the International Criminal Court (ICC) [official website] advocated for the conviction of former Congo military leader Bosco Ntaganda [BBC profile; JURIST news archive], on charges [case information] including murder, rape, conscripting child soldiers and sexual slavery. Lead prosecutor, Fatou Bensouda urged that the evidence points to Ntaganda saying,
He persecuted and attacked civilians, he murdered them, pillaged their goods, destroyed their charities and hospitals. And he enlisted and used children under  the age of 15 to participate directly in hostilities.
Beginning in September 2015, the trial [JURIST report] has involved more than 80 witnesses for crimes that Ntaganda alleged committed in 2002-2003 when he was deputy Chief of Staff of the Union of Congolose Patriots (UPC), including the murders of at least 800 civilians. Throughout the proceedings, Ntaganda has denied all charges, claiming during his testimony that he was solely acting as a peacemaker and had never harmed civilians. The defense will respond on Wednesday and Ntaganda is set to address the court following closing arguments. The ICC has yet to set a date for the verdict.

item.title: UN Human Rights Commissioner: US cuts would not be "fatal" to office --- HOLD
item.dc:creator: jlasky
item.content:encoded: The United Nations (UN) High Commissioner for Human Rights, Zeid Ra’ad al-Hussein, stated on Wednesday that the threatened funding cuts from the United State's would not stop his office from operating. Last Thursday, U.S. National Security Adviser, John Bolton, stated [AP report] the US will cut contributions to the human rights office. Hussein added he hoped other countries would not do the same.  Hussein is set to step down as Commissioner [Jurist report] at the end of this month. Since 1994, the US has supplied at least 22% of the total UN budget [UN assessment of contributions].

item.title: White House counsel to resign in the fall --- HOLD
item.dc:creator: lfares
item.content:encoded:
[JURIST] President Trump announced [Bloomberg report] on Tuesday that White House counsel Don McGahn will resign this fall. According to Trump, he will be leaving the post shortly after the confirmation hearings for the United States Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh [Biography backgrounder]. The announcement comes just two weeks after reports emerged [New York Times report] alleging that McGahn has been extensively cooperating with special counsel Robert Mueller's investigation into potential Russian interference in this past election. According to the reports, McGahn voluntarily provided over 30 hours of testimony regarding a number of incidents concerning Trump. Claims have emerged that, in his testimony, McGahn discussed Trump's firing of former FBI Director James Comey and Trump's insistence that Attorney General Jeff Sessions play a significant role in the oversight of the Russian interference investigation. The announcement came via the following Tweet on Trump's account:

White House Counsel Don McGahn will be leaving his position in the fall, shortly after the confirmation (hopefully) of Judge Brett Kavanaugh to the United States Supreme Court. I have worked with Don for a long time and truly appreciate his service!

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell [official website] expressed [The Hill report] his sadness over the news, stating that his departure will be a loss for the country. A number of other Republican senators and political figures also expressed their best wishes to McGahn as he prepares to leave his post.

item.title: Sweeping net neutrality bill heads to California governor---DNP
item.dc:creator: emccarthy
item.content:encoded: California's legislature approved a net neutrality bill [text] on Friday that some are calling the most sweeping net neutrality standards in the country [Variety report]. The bill establishes net neutrality rules by "prohibiting Internet Service providers (ISPs) from engaging in activities that interfere with a user's ability to access content on the internet." Specifically, it will make it unlawful for an ISP to block lawful content, engage in paid prioritization, unreasonably interfere with, or unreasonably disadvantage, a user's ability to select, access, and use lawful internet content, applications, services, or devices, among others. The bill seeks to prohibit Internet service providers (ISPs) from "throttling" traffic, or slowing it down based on content or users. The California bill passed in the Assembly 61-18, with all 55 Assembly Democrats and 6 Republicans voting in favor. It passed in the Senate * to *. The bill heads to the desk of Governor Jerry Brown, who must sign it by September 30. On Monday, the Internet Association along with a number of other trade groups, filed a brief [JURIST report] in the DC Circuit urging the court to reinstate net neutrality rules removed by the FCC in 2017, as have attorneys general for 22 states, including California, and DC [JURIST report]. Since net neutrality's repeal, several states have, by way of legislature or executive order, established their own rules, including Montana, the first, New York, Oregon, and others [JURIST reports].

item.title: Cambodia court extends pre-trial detention of former opposition leader Kem Sokha---HOLD
item.dc:creator: srohtla
item.content:encoded: The Phnom Penh Municipal Court in Cambodia extended [Khmer Times Report] the pre-trial detention of former opposition leader, Kem Sokha, on Thursday. Judge Ky Rithy directed the hearing with deputy prosecutor Sieng Sok at the Trapeang Phlong prison in the Tboung Khmum region. Kem Sokha has been imprisoned [JURIST Report] there since last fall on charges of treason for allegedly attempting to overthrow the government. Sokha was denied bail [JURIST Report] earlier in August. The order to extend his detention was made on the grounds that his release could pose problems for national security. The prosecution emphasized that Sokha's release could pressure witnesses and that imprisonment was necessary to keep him from fleeing. The counsel for Sokha's defense were disappointed in the ruling commenting that "it's been one year and there has been nothing for the court to investigate" and they will contemplate an appeal.

item.title: Israeli farmers file warcrimes complaint against hamas--DNP
item.dc:creator: khall
item.content:encoded: A group of Israeli farmed filed warcrimes charges against Hamas in the International Criminal Court (ICC) [official website] on Tuesday.

item.title: Guatemalan president bans UN anti-corruption commission from the country---EDIT
item.dc:creator: chsu
item.content:encoded: Last week, Guatemalan president Jimmy Morales announced [Twitter post] that the United Nation's International Commission against Impunity in Guatemala (CICIG) [official website] will not longer be welcome in the Latin American nation. The announcement has stirred much controversy domestically. At the request of the Guatemalan government, the United Nations chartered the CICIG to conduct independent investigations pertaining to matters of corruption and illicit activities involving illegal security groups and clandestine security organizations. It was also given the power to act as an independent prosecutor. The commission also considers the human rights implications behind such activities. The CICIG's charter will not expire until 2019. Morales entered office by a wide margin, replacing his predecessor, Otto Perez, who was ousted following corruption scandals. Initially, the country thought Morales a political outsider who was "neither corrupt nor a thief", but two years into his presidency, Morales' administration became plagued with corruption that is little different from his predecessor.

item.title: Supreme Court of India Overturns 160-Year-Old Ban on Homosexuality---HOLD
item.dc:creator: mmarotta
item.content:encoded:
On Thursday the Supreme Court of India announced that it would decriminalize homosexuality throughout the nation, with the ruling declaring that "criminalizing carnal intercourse under Section 377 is irrational, indefensible, and manifestly arbitrary." [Supreme Court Ruling, PDF]. Section 377 is a 160-year-old law that was written during India's British Colonial Era, modeled after the Buggery Act of 1533 which criminalizes "crimes against the order of nature," and applied to homosexual relationships. Until now, Indians who engaged in homosexual relations could be sentenced to prison for terms of between 10 years and life. [Section 377, PDF]. Dancer Navtej Johar [Profile] petitioned the court in April 2016 following the 2013 Supreme Court upholding of Section 377. [Article] The court heard the case between January and July of 2018 and reserved its verdict until September 6. This judgement follows a 2017 Supreme Court ruling that declared sexual orientation as an attribute of privacy.
“Sexual orientation is an essential attribute of privacy. Discrimination against an individual on the basis of sexual orientation is deeply offensive to the dignity and self-worth of the individual. Equality demands that the sexual orientation of each individual in society must be protected on an even platform. The right to privacy and the protection of sexual orientation lie at the core of the fundamental rights guaranteed by Articles 14, 15 and 21 of the Constitution.”
This ruling, however, upheld Section 377 and homosexuality remained a criminal act until September 6, 2018. Activists in India and around the world are celebrating this landmark case as a large step in the international battle for LGBT rights.

item.title: Argentina prosecutor seeks probe into $50 billion loan agreement with IMF---EDIT
item.dc:creator: zuram
item.content:encoded: An Argentinian Federal prosecutor announced that he will [The Bubble report] ask a federal judge on Wednesday to approve a probe into a $50 billion loan agreement between President Mauricio Macri's administration and the International Monetary Fund (IMF) [official website]. This push to investigate the Macri government comes as the Argentinian Peso has plummeted in value with experts suggesting that inflation will reach 40% this year [Bloomberg report]. In addition, the Macri administration has been forced to pledge further austerity and tax exports. Politically, Macri is seen as weak entering an election year. This news comes within a month of former President Christina Kirchner having her house raided [NYT report] as part of an anti-graft campaign.

item.title: SEC settles charges against digital currency company TokenLot --- HOLD
item.dc:creator: eslobe
item.content:encoded: The United States Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) [Official website] announced on Tuesday that TokenLot LLC and owners Lenny Kugel and Eli Lewitt settled charges [Press Release] with the SEC after the company was charged with acting as an unregistered broker-dealer in the sale of digital tokens. TokenLot handled over 200 digital tokens and allowed the purchase of digital tokens in Initial Coin Offerings (ICOs). TokenLot was required to register as a broker-dealer by the SEC because the profits of the company were obtained through trading profits and a percentage of ICO earnings. This is the first time that the SEC has charged and unregistered broker-dealer for selling digital tokens. TokenLot was fined $478,929 and Kugel and Lewitt were each fined $45,000. The remaining digital assets of TokenLot are to be destroyed by a third party. Kugel and Lewitt are also bared from participating in the industry and from participating in penny stocks. TokenLot was noted as taking "prompt cooperation and remedial actions."  A federal judge ruled in March that cryptocurrencies can be regulated [JURIST report] by federal agencies. The SEC had previously denied [JURIST report] a request to create an exchange-traded fund (ETF) for the virtual currency Bitcoin. The Philippines Securities and Exchange Commission has increased [JURIST Commentary] oversight on cryptocurrencies and ICOs in recent months.

item.title: A Louisiana town mayor issues memo banning Nike products from recreational facilities---HOLD
item.dc:creator: atomlinson
item.content:encoded:
The mayor of a Louisiana town issued a memo [text] on Wednesday banning the city's recreation facilities from buying Nike products. Kenner Mayor E. Ben Zahn III's [official profile] memo ordered that the city's recreation facilities receive approval from the city for purchases made by sports booster clubs for "apparel, shoes, athletic equipment and/or any athletic product" and "under no circumstances" will any Nike products, or Nike logo bearing products, be acceptable for purchase. The decision to ban Nike apparel comes days after the company's announcement that former NFL quarterback Colin Kaepernick was hired for its new advertising campaign [CBS post], which to date has caused a lot of controversy from those with differing political views. In light of the wave of disapproval caused by his memo, Zahn released a statement [press release, PDF] on Monday defending his position. According to Zahn, his decision to ban Nike products was made in the interest to "protect taxpayer dollars from being used in a political campaign."
In Kenner, like every city, our citizens and our taxpayers cover a wide spectrum of political philosophies and agendas. We must respect all of those agendas and philosophies. So, when a company uses its advertising as its own political megaphone, government should be fair to all of its people and not allow taxpayer dollars to be used to help that company push its own political agenda. My decision is only to protect taxpayer dollars from being used in a political campaign. My internal memo draws the line on letting companies profit from taxpayers by espousing political beliefs. The government will not let taxpayer dollars be used to promote a company's or individual's political position, platform or principle. That's my position as a matter of fairness to all.
In response to the statement issued by Mayor Zahn, News Orelans Mayor LaToya Cantrell [official profile] also released a statement [press release] on Monday calling Zahn's order "out of step" with the city's values and that the New Orleans International Airport located in Kenner will not be subject to the order. On Sunday Kenner Council Gregory Carroll announced his intent [Facebook post] to meet with the city's mayor and other council members to work on rescinding this order, finding the order "disturbing".

item.title: Palestine files ICC complaint against Israel---HOLD
item.dc:creator: lfares
item.content:encoded:
Saeb Erekat, Secretary General of the Palestine Liberation Organization (PLO) [official website], has stated [AP report] that Palestine has filed a new complaint against Israel on Tuesday in the International Criminal Court (ICC) [official website] over Israel's plan to demolish a Palestinian village in the West Bank which they claim may potentially amount to  war crimes [PressTV report]. The village at issue is named Kahn al-Ahmar and Israel maintains that it was illegally built. Israel has also stated that it has offered a plan to resettle the residents of Kahn al-Ahmar approximately 7 miles away from where the village currently stands. The Supreme Court of Israel [official website] approved [BBC report] the government's Kahn al-Ahmar demolition plan last week. The Palestinian government handed over the plan to the ICC back in July. Commenting on the matter, French Foreign Minister Jean-Yves Le Drian [official profile] stated that France has been paying particularly close attention to the demolition of Kahn al-Ahmar because of its location. According to Le Drian, the region is strategically important for a two-state solution with Jerusalem acting as the capital. Le Drian also voiced concerns over the humanitarian impacts the village's demolition may have on its inhabitants and their potential displacement. Back in May 2018, a German Federal Foreign Office Spokesperson issued a statement [text] voicing many of the same concerns. The official stated:
The [German] Government is extremely concerned that the Bedouin village of Khan al Ahmar could soon be demolished and its inhabitants resettled against their will. Khan al Ahmar is located near the so-called E1 area between Jerusalem and the Israeli settlement of Ma’ale Adumim. If settlements were to be constructed here, this would significantly diminish the prospects for a contiguous Palestinian state – and thus also the feasibility of a two-state solution.
In a joint statement [UK press release] issued on Monday, the governments of France, Germany, Italy, Spain, and the United Kingdom asked the Israeli government not to go ahead with the demolition of the village despite the Supreme Court of Israel's ruling. The complaint comes after the Trump administration announced [WSJ report] the closure of the PLO's office in Washington D.C. on Monday after its leaders refused to enter into peace talks with Israel. John Bolton, a Trump administration national security adviser, stated that the act was one of solidarity with Israel. Palestinian officials stated that the move will only escalate matters in the region.

item.title: Federal judge denies bail to five New Mexico compound defendants---DNP
item.dc:creator: lmoffutt
item.content:encoded: Magistrate Judge Kirtan Khalsa of the US District Court for the District of New Mexico [official website] on Wednesday denied bail to  The defendants include: Jany Leveille,35; Siraj Ibn Wahhaj, 40; Hujrah Wahhaj, 37; Subhanah Wahhaj, 35; and Lucas Morton, 40.

item.title: Chinese Government extends offer to Trump Administration to enter into talks regarding tariffs on $200 Billion of goods.---DNP
item.dc:creator: zuram
item.content:encoded: Chinese Government extends offer to Trump Administration to enter into talks regarding tariffs on $200 Billion of goods.

item.title: France president acknowledges military’s systemic use of torture in Algerian War---HOLD
item.dc:creator: zuram
item.content:encoded: French President Emmanuel Macron while visiting [France24, Report] the widow of Maurice Audin[BBC Report], officially acknowledged the French military's systematic use of torture during the Algerian War in the 1950s and 60s. Maurice Audin was a 25-year-old mathematician and communist at the University of Algiers and supported the Algerian Independence movement, he disappeared during the war. Macron revealed that Maurice was in fact tortured by the French military. Macron in his remarks [France24, Report] to Mrs. Audin said, "The only thing I do is acknowledge the truth...It's up to me to apologize, so you're not telling me anything, we're restoring some of what needs to be done."  President Macron is set to open archives that have information about Algerian and French citizens that went missing during the 6-year civil war. Marcon's move is seen as step forward for France to acknowledge and reconcile their colonial past, one which France has often been silent publically.

item.title: Belgian court refuses to extradite Spanish rapper convicted for "terror lyrics"---HOLD
item.dc:creator: mmarotta
item.content:encoded: On Monday a court in Ghent, Belgium refused to extradite rapper Arenas Beltran (stage name "Valtònyc") after he was found guilty of insulting the monarchy and encouraging terrorism through his lyrics. Valtònyc is one of several rappers convicted in a Spanish crackdown on explicit lyrics, especially those that insult the monarchy or threaten members of the royal family. Critics have raised concern at this alleged suppression of free speech, and Amnesty International condemned [statement] the policy in March. "Sending rappers to jail for song lyrics and outlawing political satire demonstrates how narrow the boundaries of acceptable online speech have become in Spain," they said in their statement. Valtònyc was convicted in February for rapping the lyrics "the King has a rendezvous at the village square, with a noose around his neck," in the song "Fascism is cured by dying" [video, in Spanish] and disappeared after a sentence of three-and-a-half years in prison. He is the first artist since the fall of the Franco regime in 1975 to be found guilty of anti-monarchy sentiment. About Belgium's refusal to extradite him, Valtònyc tweeted [tweet, in Catalan] "when you have competent courts and true justice, you are not alone."

item.title: London mayor calls for another referendum on Britain’s EU membership---HOLD
item.dc:creator: zuram
item.content:encoded:
On Friday, London Mayor Sadiq Khan writing in an article[Guardian Opinion] for the Guardian called for another referendum on Britain’s EU membership, claiming the prime minister has been mishandling the Brexit [BBC, Profile] negotiations. On March 29th, the United Kingdoms is set to divorce from the European Union. However, Prime Minister Theresa May's government has yet to establish a deal domestically for terms and conditions to leave. Mayor Sadiq Khan wrote the following highlighting that source of tension,
Until now, I’ve held out hope the government would finally get its act together, start listening to the advice of employers, trade unions and everyone who has a stake in getting this right and seek the best possible deal with the EU – putting the national interest ahead of narrow party politics. But it’s clear this prospect is now dead in the water.
The current administration has consistently rejected the idea of a second referendum. Khan's support of a second referendum is seen as putting pressure on Labour leader Jeremy Orby to remove his opposition for a second referendum. [Reuters, Report]

item.title: Federal judge rules Georgia may use e-voting despite hacking risks---HOLD
item.dc:creator: akoltonowski
item.content:encoded:
A federal judge said on Monday that Georgia may use electronic ballots for the upcoming mid-term elections, after a lawsuit filed in May 2017 against Georgia's Secretary of State sought to rid of Direct Recording Electronic (DRE) voting machines. U.S. District Judge Amy Totenberg ruled [Reuters] that while it is important for citizens to know their ballots are not compromised, voters also must rely on a smooth process, especially in an approaching election. Switching to a paper-based voting system in such a short time frame before the midterms may "just as readily jeopardize the upcoming elections, voter turnout, and the orderly administration of the election." Following the 2016 presidential election and Georgia's own potential data brach of 7.5 million voters, citizens have been concerned with hacking, voter fraud and voting machine vulnerabilities.

The biggest critique [Atlanta Business Chronicle] of Georgia’s all-electronic voting machines is a vulnerability of hacking and the inability to audit the machines without an independent paper record for recounts and accuracy checks.

The judge acknowledged the State of Georgia failed to ensure their DRE machines were secure. "The state's posture in this litigation–and some of the testimony and evidence presented–indicated that the defendants and state election officials had buried their heads in the sand,”  The judge’s decision to reject their request to require paper ballots in November does not affect the underlying lawsuit, which will continue.

item.title: Federal judge overturns Pennsylvania ban on political donations from gambling industry---HOLD
item.dc:creator: elowman
item.content:encoded:
Judge Sylvia Rambo of the US District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania [official website] ruled [opinion] on Wednesday that the state's ban on campaign contributions from individuals owning or holding stake in the gambling industry was unconstitutionality broad.  The General Assembly said:
Banning all types of political campaign contributions by certain persons subject to this part is necessary to prevent corruption and the appearance of corruption that may arise when political campaign contributions and gaming regulated under this part are intermingled.
Aside from casino owners, the ban [act] includes slot-machine licensees, slot machine manufacturers, and certain employees. The two plaintiffs, Pasquale T. Deon, Sr. and Maggie Hardy Magerko, applied to be licensed as "principals," under the Gaming Act, making them ineligible to make political contributions, although both plaintiffs desire to do so. Because political contributions are protected under the First Amendment, bans on campaign donations must be narrowly tailored and serve a compelling government interest. The district court said  that "the ban in its current form goes much further than necessary to achieve its stated purpose of eliminating corruption and the appearance of corruption..." and called the statute "unconstitutionally disproportionate."  The judge wrote that the legislature could constitutionally modify the law by allowing donations but placing a limit on the amount, or narrowing the class of persons who are banned from donating.  Earlier this month a federal appeals court ruled [JURIST report] that Missouri cannot ban contributions between political action committees. In 2017 the Supreme Court upheld [JURIST report] advertising disclosure requirements during campaigns.

item.title: Virginia prisons ban visitors from using certain menstrual products over contraband concerns---HOLD
item.dc:creator: atomlinson
item.content:encoded:
The Virginia Department of Corrections [official website] announced [Twitter post] on Thursday plans to invoke a hygiene products ban on female visitors next month due to security concerns. The new policy will ban female visitors from wearing tampons or menstrual cups into state prisons. According to the Department the policy will prevent the smuggling of contraband into prisons. Lisa Kinney, spokeswoman for the Department, stated, "If someone chooses to visit a Virginia Department of Corrections inmate, he or she cannot have anything hidden inside a body cavity. There have been many instances in which visitors have attempted to smuggle drugs into our prisons by concealing those drugs in a body cavity[.] Claire Gastanaga, Executive Director of the ACLU of Virginia [official website] released a statement [press release] on Monday calling the policy "simply unacceptable."
Helping people who are house in jail or prison stay connected to friends, families, and communities is critical to rehabilitation and eventual, successful re-entry to society. Any policy that discourages visitors is, therefore, one that should be subject to the most exacting and careful review. In addition, a policy like this one that requires those who wish to visit people who are incarcerated to set aside their dignity and health is simply unacceptable.
Gastanaga urges the Department's Director Harold Clarke to reverse the policy and any such policy that limits visitation rights based on choice of hygiene products.

item.title: Appellate Court rules Uber can prevent class-action lawsuits by independent contractors---HOLD
item.dc:creator: mmarotta
item.content:encoded: On Tuesday the 9th Circuit Court of Appeals in San Francisco reviewed and reversed an appeal for class-action arbitration by employees dissatisfied with their classification as "independent contractors" with the company. In its decision the court cited the April 2018 case [PDF, text] Dynamex Operations West, Inc. v. Superior Court of Los Angeles County (Ct.App. 2/7 B249546) in which an "independent contractor" is defined, in part, as "a worker who is free from the control and direction of the company in connection with performing the work, both in reality and under the terms of the relevant contract, a worker who performs work that is outside the usual course of the company’s business, or a worker who customarily engages in an independently established trade, occupation, or business of the same nature as the work being performed for the company." In a press release [text] Uber CEO Travis Kalanick admitted that Uber and its drivers have not always shared the best relationship. "We are so pleased that this settlement recognizes that drivers should remain as independent contractors, not employees," he said. The settlement in the case requires that Uber pay $84 million to plaintiffs, with an additional $16 million to follow if the company goes public but in a loss for some drivers, they will continue to be classified as 'independent contractors' rather than employees.

item.title: Federal judge blocks Kentucky Medicaid work requirement
item.dc:creator: emccarthy
item.content:encoded:
A federal judge on Friday blocked [opinion, PDF] a proposed Kentucky Medicaid plan that would include work requirements as a condition of receiving the state's subsidized health coverage. Under the proposed Kentucky plan, titled Kentucky HEALTH, the state would impose “community-engagement” requirements for both traditional and expansion Medicaid populations. It also included a new mandate that would require that those recipients work (or participate in other qualifying activities) for at least 80 hours each month as a condition of receiving health coverage. The project also called for, among other things, increased premiums and more stringent reporting requirements. US District Judge James Boasberg wrote that the HHS Secretary failed to question the impact on health care — an omission that was "arbitrary and capricious."
At bottom, the record shows that 95,000 people would lose Medicaid coverage, and yet the Secretary paid no attention to that deprivation. Nor did he address how Kentucky HEALTH would otherwise help 'furnish . . . medical assistance.' In other words, he glossed over 'the impact of the state’s project' on the individuals whom Medicaid 'was enacted to protect.'
The complaint was filed in January [JURIST report] in the US District Court for the District of Columbia [official website] by three organizations representing 15 Kentucky Medicaid recipients, who argued that the change would harm Kentuckians across the state by limiting their access to health services, including check-ups, diabetes treatment, mental health services, blood pressure monitoring and treatment, and vision and dental care. Former Trump administration acting Secretary of Health and Human Services [official website] Eric Hargan approved [JURIST report] states' Medicaid work requirements in January.

item.title: Amnesty calls on Egypt lawmakers to reject online censorship laws
item.dc:creator: srohtla
item.content:encoded:
Amnesty International (AI) called [press release] Monday for the Egyptian parliament to vote down proposed laws [text, in Arabic] that would increase the government's control over online content. Najia Bounaim [Twitter profile], Director of Campaigns in North Africa, said,
These proposed laws would increase the Egyptian government's already broad powers to monitor, censor and block social media and blogs, as well as criminalize content that violates vaguely defined political, social or religious norms.
If the laws are passed, law enforcement will be able to monitor and block websites in the name of crime prevention and protection of national security. The laws on online media would also increase the regulation of the media to potentially block disfavored sites. Amnesty reports that "Over the past year, the Egyptian authorities have blocked 500 websites including independent news platforms and pages belonging to rights groups."

item.title: Federal judge orders two month delay in Michael Flynn sentencing
item.dc:creator: lmoffutt
item.content:encoded: The US District Court for the District of Columbia [official website] on Friday ordered [text, PDF] a two month delay in Michael Flynn's sentencing hearing for his guilty plea [JURIST report] concerning charges related to making false statements to the FBI. The order comes in response to requests from both Special Counsel Robert Muller and Flynn's defense team for additional time before proceeding with sentencing. Flynn, the former national security advisor to Donald Trump, pled guilty in December to charges concerning two statements he made. In the first, Flynn denied making a request to a Russian ambassador to “refrain from escalating the situation” after the US imposed sanctions on Russia and Flynn denied recalling that the Russian ambassador then stated they will “moderate” their response due the the request. As to the second, Flynn denied asking a Russian ambassador to delay or defeat a United Nations Security Council resolution. Flynn also denied receiving a response to the request. The order grants both parties an additional 60 days to prepare for the sentencing hearing, or no later than August 24, 2018.

item.title: Malaysia former Prime Minister arrested in corruption investigation
item.dc:creator: whibbitts
item.content:encoded: The former Prime Minister of Malaysia,  Najib Razak, was arrested on Tuesday due to his alleged involvement in theft from a state-owned development company called 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB) [BBC report].  Razak is accused of stealing $700 million dollars from the fund, and the United States Department of Justice [press release] alleges that a total of $4.5 billion has been misappropriated from the company since 2009. Razak was an owner of 1MDB and is set to face charges that reportedly include [Al Jazeera report] money laundering and misappropriation of property. The arrest and charges come after a raid [Al Jazeera report] on properties linked to the former PM in which $273 million worth of items and jewelry were seized and a special task force [JURIST report] was formed. Razak is currently spending the night detained at the Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission and will appear in court tomorrow morning.

item.title: Federal judge blocks parts of California Immigrant Worker Protection Act
item.dc:creator: whibbitts
item.content:encoded:
Judge John Mendez of the US District Court for the Eastern District of California [official website] on Wednesday blocked [order, PDF] the enforcement of provisions of California's Immigrant Worker Protection Act [text] that would have fined employers who consent to immigration enforcement activities not mandated by federal law. The act prohibits employers from providing consent to an immigration officer to "enter any nonpublic areas of a place of labor," and from verifying employees' immigration status except as required by federal law. Judge Mendez, citing the Supremacy Clause of the United States Constitution [text], wrote that:
As in other intergovernmental immunity cases, the imposition of civil fines (like the imposition of taxes) turns on whether an employer chooses to work with federal immigration enforcement. These fines are a clear attempt to 'meddl[e] with federal government activities indirectly by singling out for regulation those who deal with the government...'  The Court does not find Defendant’s argument that the law is neutral convincing.
The preliminary injunction only applies to private employers. Judge Mendez refrained from enjoining California's ability to review immigration detention facilities within its borders. This recent case comes after other federal rulings concerning immigration enforcement and sanctuary cities. In June a federal court ruled [JURIST report] that Philadelphia could maintain its status as a sanctuary city. And in March, a federal court upheld [JURIST report] a Texas law banning sanctuary cities.

item.title: EPA administrator Pruitt resigns
item.dc:creator: emccarthy
item.content:encoded: US President Donald Trump announced [Twitter post] Thursday the resignation of Scott Pruitt as Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency [official website]. "Within the Agency Scott has done an outstanding job, and I will always be thankful to him for this," Trump said. Trump noted that current Deputy Adminstrator Andrew Wheeler will serve as acting administrator. "I have no doubt that Andy will continue on with our great and lasting EPA agenda. We have made tremendous progress and the future of the EPA is very bright!" At the EPA, Pruitt has pushed an agenda centered around deregulation, including the EPA's halting of a regulation that required mining companies [JURIST report] to show that they have enough funding for the cleanup of harmful substances prior to starting any mining operations. In May, a coalition of 17 states and the District of Columbia filed suit [JURIST report] against the EPA to defend an Obama-era rule on vehicle emissions standards.
