item.title: Rights groups criticize immigration form for detained parents
item.dc:creator: srohtla
item.content:encoded: According to an Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) form [text, PDF ] first obtained by NBC News  [NBC report] Tuesday, detained immigrant parents, even those with pending asylum claims, must choose between returning to their country with or without their children. The form is to be read to the parents in a language that they know and has them sign for either reunification and group deportation with their children or to return to their country and allow their children to "pursue available claims of relief." After the June 26 ruling [JURIST Report] by California Federal Judge Dana Sabraw, the government must reunite parents and children but is not obligated to let families stay together in the United States while their asylum claim is being decided. The form is being described by lawyers as coercive, persuading parents to give up their right to remain in the United States to be reunited with their children. ACLU attorney Lee Gelernt commented [Washington Post report], “there’s no reason the government should be asking about removal at the same time as reunification . . . The ruling makes clear that parents are entitled to get their children back” without being “contingent upon them waiving their right to contest removal.”

item.title: ICE asks for more time to reunite detained immigrant families
item.dc:creator: emccarthy
item.content:encoded:
The US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) [official website] agency said [notice, PDF] Thursday it needs more time to accurately identify the parents of detained immigrant children. The response follows a June 26 court order [JURIST report] in the US District Court for the Southern District of California [official website]. ICE wrote that they would be using DNA testing to identify the parents and that they had been
[W]orking diligently on complying with the Court’s reunification directives...understand the urgent concerns underpinning the Court’s order... and have dedicated immense resources and effort to reunifying families, and personnel at the highest levels of the agencies have been involved in implementing the Court’s directives... Although HHS is moving expeditiously to undertake these DNA tests, that process takes meaningful time, even when it is expedited—as this Court has implicitly recognized.
The original injunction [order, PDF] applies to all immigrant families, unless “the parent is unfit or presents a danger to the child.” The US government is barred from continuing to detaining and separating migrant families, and if detained parents are released their minor child or children must also be released. The court gave the government a 14 day deadline for reunifying families with children under the age of five, and 30 days for minor children over five.

item.title: France Constitutional Council rules for farmer who helped migrants
item.dc:creator: whibbitts
item.content:encoded: France's Constitutional Council ruled [press release, in French] Friday that a farmer who aided migrants crossing France's border with Italy was immune from prosecution because he operated on the principle of "fraternity" during the course of his actions. According to the council, this is the first time they have "held that fraternity is a principle with constitutional value," citing Article 2 of the French Constitution [text] which states in part that "The maxim of the Republic shall be “Liberty, Equality, Fraternity”." The council also noted, however, that "it is up to the legislator to reconcile the principle of fraternity and safeguarding of public order." Last August, the farmer, Cedric Herrou, received [Reuters report] a four-month suspended jail sentence for helping over 3,000 migrants travel from the Italian border to his farm. This ruling effectively overturns his sentence. The European Union, which France is a member of, has been dealing with an ongoing refugee crisis since 2015 with many EU nations responding differently to the pressures put on them. In June the UN high commissioner for human rights condemned [JURIST report] Hungarian legislation criminalizing residents who aid asylum-seekers and undocumented immigrants. In May, the Greek parliament passed a law [JURIST report] simplifying its asylum procedures in an effort to ease the burden on its overcrowded refugee camps.

item.title: European Parliament votes down copyright reform bill
item.dc:creator: emccarthy
item.content:encoded: The European Parliament [official website] voted down a highly-debated copyright bill [proposal text, PDF] Thursday, which would have made sweeping changes to the copyright regulation of online media. It was a bill [procedure file] big firms such as Google and Facebook argued would stifle creativity and sharing, as it aimed to regulate these companies' monitoring more closely for infringements. License holders — publishers, media companies, individual creators — supported the bill's aim at protecting creative content. The vote was close with 318 against, 278 in favor, and 31 abstaining. The bill now heads back to Parliament where lawmakers can add amendments, and further discuss. It will be up for debate, amendment, and a vote during the next plenary session in September. In a statement [press release] Rapporteur Axel Voss of Germany said, “I regret that a majority of MEPs did not support the position which I and the Legal Affairs Committee have been advocating. But this is part of the democratic process. We will now ... attempt to address peoples’ concerns whilst bringing our copyright rules up to date with the modern digital environment.”

item.title: Federal court rules north carolina congressional districts unconstitutional---HOLD
item.dc:creator: khall
item.content:encoded:
The United States District Court for the Middle District of North Carolina [official website] ruled [opinion, PDF] on Monday that the partisan gerrymander of North Carolina's federal congressional districts were unconstitutional and suggested that the November general election may have to be postponed. The decision was rendered by a 2-1 vote of a three-judge panel, which had initially deemed the congressional districts unconstitutional in January but was temporarily stayed [JURIST report] by the Supreme Court on appeal. Then, in June, the Supreme Court vacated [JURIST report] the Middle District's judgment and sent the case back to the lower courts with instructions to be consistent with its recent political gerrymandering decision in Gill v. Whitford [opinion, PDF].  Using the language of the Court's decision in Gill, the Middle District found that the plaintiffs, Common Cause [advocacy website] and the League of Women Voters of North Carolina [advocacy website], had standing to sue on behalf of voters in the districts at issue under the U.S. Constitution's Equal Protections Clause [materials]. The court explained that:
a plaintiff asserting a partisan vote dilution claim under the Equal Protection Clause faces the heightened burden of proving that a legislative mapdrawer’s predominant purpose in drawing the lines of a particular district was to subordinate adherents of one political party and entrench a rival party in power. . . .
[Here] the General Assembly expressly directed the legislators and consultant responsible for drawing the 2016 Plan to rely on “political data”—that is, past election results specifying whether, and to what extent, particular voting precincts had favored Republican or Democratic candidates, and therefore were likely to do so in the future—to draw a districting plan that would ensure Republican candidates would prevail in the vast majority of the State’s congressional districts, and would continue to do so in future elections ... And the Republican-controlled General Assembly achieved that goal. As ... the 2016 Plan led to Republican candidates prevailing by “safe” margins in the vast majority of the State’s thirteen congressional districts.
The Middle District also rejected arguments that the districts be preserved until after the November election, which poses a number of issues given the fact that the North Carolina primaries have already taken place. Instead, the court proposed that the state could hold a general election without a primary in constitutionally sufficient districts or hold the primary in November and the general election sometime before congress is seated in January 2019.
It is likely that this issue will work its way to the Supreme Court, but the vacancy left by Justice Kennedy's retirement could result a split-decision, which would mean the lower Middle District's decision would stand. North Carolina is currently represented by 10 republicans and three democrats.

item.title: UN General Assembly---dnp
item.dc:creator: emccarthy
item.content:encoded:
UN General Assembly kicks off with multilateralism theme---dnp
As the United Nations General Assembly opened its general debate [press release] Tuesday, Secretary-General António Guterres called on members to prioritize and act on climate change, safety in cyberspace, multilateralism, among other things. A total of 34 world leaders addressed the General Assembly Tuesday and Wednesday.
Each shared their priorities in the world's most pressing challenges, including climate change, the elimination of extreme poverty, nuclear proliferation, and others.
President of the General Assembly María Fernanda Espinosa Garcés of Ecuador said that multilateralism is the only viable response to global problems, and emphasized seven areas in particular: gender equality and the empowerment of women, implementation of new global agreements on refugees and migrants, the creation of decent work opportunities, protection of the environment, the rights of persons with disabilities, the revitalization of the United Nations, and peace and security.
Among the 34 who spoke was US President Donald Trump, who said that nations can work better together when they respect their neighbors and defended their people’s interests. Trump also accused Iran's leaders of sowing chaos, death and destruction, disrespecting the borders and sovereignty of neighboring states, the press release said.
President Hassan Rouhani of Iran countered that Iran has thus far complied with all its commitments according to the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), and criticized the US for pulling out of its accord with them.
According to the statement, President Emmanuel Macron of France said that "unilateral pursuit leads directly to isolation and conflict. The task is not to fuel tensions but to put forth a new agenda through dialogue and multilateralism. Trade imbalances can be solved with common rules that guarantee fair competition, not bilateral dealings."

item.title: Russia adopts more flexible retirement pension bill---HOLD
item.dc:creator: chsu
item.content:encoded: A bill aimed at improving the state level retirement pension system in Russia was adopted [article, PNP] by the State Duma. The bill aims to allow Russian citizens the right to choose their own retirement age. Meanwhile, men will be entitled to a national pension beginning at the age of 60 and women will be entitled to one beginning at the age of 55. The bill was introduced by the political faction, "A Just Russia" (aka "Fair Russia") [official website] to the parliamentary body. A Just Russia, headed by Sergei Mironov. The government has been deliberating the issue of pension retirement age throughout the year. In July, the Duma adopted a version of the bill that would raise male retirement ages to 65 and women to 63. In August, President Vladimir Putin proposed a modification of the bill to reduce the retirement age, notable to age 60 for women.

item.title: UN and Congo president at odds on upcoming election --- HOLD
item.dc:creator: lfares
item.content:encoded: [JURIST] The current but outgoing President of the Democratic Republic of Congo (DCR),  Joseph Kabila [Aljazeera backgrounder] and the United Nation's Human Rights Council [official webiste] are taking opposite positions on the upcoming elections set to take place in the DCR at the end of the year. According to Kabila [Reuters report], he will strive to ensure that the elections will be peaceful and credible. The UN, on the other hand, has voiced its concerns [VOA report] regarding the rise in human rights violations and the restriction of civil rights in the DCR, calling the credibility of the upcoming election into question. Kabila announced last month that he would agree not to continue to exceed the DCR's constitutional presidential limit, which expired for Kabila in 2016, but would rather seek re-election. The announcement eased the intensity of protests and the anti-Kabila sentiment that built after DCR government forces killed dozens of anti-Kabilia protestors. In his statements before the UN, Kabila stated that, although he still perceives many challenges facing the DCR, his decision to hold these elections is, in his mind, "irreversible." He also stated that, in his belief, the political situation in his country has become increasingly transparent and stable. However, the UN has noted a pattern of Kabila's government taking measures to suppress the freedom of expression and assembly in his country since June 2017. According to the UN, with less than three months to go before the election, there has been a 35% increase in human rights violations perpetrated by DCR police forces. The acts of these police forces, according to the UN, are geared predominantly towards restricting the space for and ability to engage in protests and political assembly. The UN fears that these violations will only intensify as the elections draw closer. Marie-Ange Mushobekwa Likulia, the DCR's Minister of Human Rights, responded to the UN's allegations by stating that, although she acknowledges that her country must do more in the way of protecting human rights, they have made progress towards that goal. Likulia echoed the statements of Kabila by asserting that there will be no interference in the upcoming elections and added that the DCR ceased engaging in the conduct underlying the UN's fears approximately three months ago. The elections are expected to be held on December 23, 2018.

item.title: Virginia officials suspend prison visitor tampon ban---HOLD
item.dc:creator: lmoffutt
item.content:encoded:
Virginia Secretary of Public and Homeland Security Safety [official website] Brian Moran on Monday suspended a Virginia Department of Corrections [official website] policy [statement] set to take place in October that sought to ban prison visitors from wearing tampons and menstrual cups. The policy was implemented to prevent visitors from concealing contraband, including drugs, in their body cavities. Upon arrival, visitors would be asked to remove prohibited products and replace them with a pads offered at the prison. The policy set forth reparations for policy offenders:
Offender visitors who have been recognized by the body scanner machine having a foreign object that could possibly be a tampon and has failed to remove such item prior to being scanned, will have their visitation terminated for the day, and will have their visitation privileges reviewed.
Activist groups spoke out against the policy and urged DOC Chief Harold Clarke to reverse the policy, saying it violates the privacy rights of female visitors. The American Civil Liberties Union of Virginia [official website] released a report, saying "a policy like this one that requires those who wish to visit people who are incarcerated to set aside their dignity and health is simply unacceptable." Moran "I understand DOC's precautionary steps to detect the rising threat of contraband, overdoses and even deaths among our offender population. A number of concerns have been raised about the new procedure." The suspension is temporary pending further review.

item.title: Poland court orders PM to correct rally comments---HOLD
item.dc:creator: arundell
item.content:encoded: On Wednesday, a court ordered [Reuters report] Polish Prime Minister Mateusz Morawiecki [official profile] to correct comments he made at a recent election campaign rally within 48 hours. During this rally Morawiecki stated, "We are spending more money in a period of 1-1.5 years on local roads than was spent by the PO-PSL coalition in 8 years." Opposition party Civic Platform (PO) [official website] brought the lawsuit in response to these comments in which the prime minister compared his government to those that came before. Opposition parties have called for the prime minister to resign immediately, prior to a crucial election.

item.title: Former Guatemalan intelligence chief acquitted of human rights violations ---HOLD
item.dc:creator: arundell
item.content:encoded:
On Wednesday, a Guatemala court acquitted [Reuters report] former military intelligence chief, José Mauricio Rodríguez Sánchez, of genocide and crimes against humanity. Two of the three judges on the panel voted in favor of the acquittal. The court ultimately found that these genocide crimes did occur, but still absolved Rodríguez of the charges. Previously in 2015, the Guatemalan Congress [official website, in Spanish] approved a resolution [JURIST report] denying any existence of genocide during the 1960-1996 Guatemalan civil war. Judge Delmar Gonzalez states,
There is no evidence that shows that the accused had knowledge of what was happening in the conflict areas. The accused could not issue orders due to the rank and position he held in the army.
The retired general was on trial for his alleged role in ordering a counterinsurgency plan that killed over 1,700 members of the Indigenous Ixil Mayans.

item.title: Mexico ex-governor sentenced to 9 years for criminal association and money laundering---HOLD
item.dc:creator: zuram
item.content:encoded: On Wednesday, the former governor of Veracruz, Javier Duarte [BBC report], was sentenced to nine years in prison and fined $58,890 pesos by a Mexican federal judge following guilty pleas for the crimes of criminal association and money laundering. While Duarte was governor of Veracruz, there were mass killings and disappearance occurred related to drug violence and the corruption of the government. In November 2011, a total 50 women went missing in the capital [The Guardian report] of Veracruz in three consecutive nights. Over the course of his governorship thousands of people disappeared and at least 17 journalists were murdered. Hundreds of bodies were later found buried in a series of clandestine mass graves. Duarte's sentence is seen as a test of impunity in Mexico, the Veracruz state authorities have seized around $120m in properties belonging to Duarte and he will likely not have to pay any damages. His guilty plea deal could lead to his freedom in three years [The Guardian report].

item.title: United Nations’ Human Rights Council (HRC) passes resolution on Venezuela human rights crisis. ---HOLD
item.dc:creator: zuram
item.content:encoded: On Thursday, the United Nations’ Human Rights Council(HRC) passed a resolution in response to the human rights crisis unfolding in Venezuela as its economy deteriorates. [Human Rights Watch] In the resolution, the council expressed distress over ongoing human rights violations in Venezuela. The resolution calls for the Venezuelan government to accept humanitarian assistance in response to “scarcity of food and medicine, the rise of malnutrition” and prevent the outbreaks of dangerous diseases. [Human Rights Watch] "It also asks the UN high commissioner for human rights to present a comprehensive report on the situation in Venezuela during the June 2019 council session, and oral updates during the March and September sessions." The vote for the resolution passed 23 to 7, with 17 abstaining.

item.title: UK Brexit cabinet members resign over trade disagreements
item.dc:creator: emccarthy
item.content:encoded:
Within 24 hours, three cabinet members tasked with coordinating the UK's leave from the European Union known as Brexit [JURIST report] have resigned. The first, Secretary of State David Davis, who submitted his resignation [text, PDF] late Sunday, was shortly followed by a junior secretary at the Department for Exiting the EU, Steve Baker. Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson announced his resignation [text, via Twitter] Monday morning. The Brexit "dream is dying, suffocated by needless self-doubt," Johnson wrote in his resignation letter. "Brexit should be about opportunity and hope. It should be a chance to do things differently, to be more nimble and dynamic." The UK is due to leave the European Union on March 29, 2019, but those involved have had difficulty agreeing on trade policy between the UK and the EU. Referencing a meeting last Friday, Davis said in his letter:
In my view the inevitable consequence of the proposed policies will be to make the supposed control by Parliament illusory rather than real. As I said at the Cabinet, the "common rule book" policy hands control of large swathes of our economy to the EU and is certainly not returning control of our laws in any really sense.
Prime Minister Theresa May also submitted a response [letter, PDF] to Davis Sunday, citing her disagreement, and belief that the proposed policy provided a "precise, responsible, and credible basis" for Brexit. In a statement to Parliament [Guardian report, YouTube] Monday, May said, "We do not agree about the best way of delivering our shared commitment to honor the result of the referendum, but I want to recognize the work of the former Secretary of State [Davis] for exiting the European Union, for the work he did to establish a new department, and to steer through parliament some of the most important legislation for generations." Following the Friday meeting, May proposed steps regarding trade [proposal, PDF] with the EU post-Brexit.

item.title: Appeals court upholds $10 billion Volkswagen diesel settlement
item.dc:creator: jbuffa
item.content:encoded: The US Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit upheld [opinion, PDF] Monday a $10 billion class action settlement against Volkswagen for a 2015 emissions cheating scandal. Volkswagen has admitted [press release] to installing devices in certain models of their diesel vehicles to have them defeat US emissions tests. Anywhere from 10-40 times the legal amount of diesel fumes were being released into the air under normal operating conditions. The action resulted in multiple class action lawsuits [JURIST archive] with nearly 500,000 people owning the affected vehicles. The lawsuit questioned the certification of the class, the approval of the settlement, and the denial of a class member's motion to opt out. All three points were approved and the settlement stands.

item.title: Myanmar charges journalists with spying
item.dc:creator: jbuffa
item.content:encoded:
Myanmar prosecutors on Monday charged two Reuters [website, link] reporters with violating the 1911 Official Secrets Act [text] by reporting on military unrest in the state of Rakhine. Thie act has been amended multiple times and is intended to protect the state from espionage and spying. Myanmar officials alleged the reporters obtained classified military documents and had the intent to share them with foreign intelligence. The reporters said they were just doing their job of reporting on international issues. The Reuters president and editor-in-chief, Stephen J. Adler, released a statement [text]:
These Reuters journalists were doing their jobs in an independent and impartial way, and there are no facts or evidence to suggest that they’ve done anything wrong or broken any law. They should be released and reunited with their families, friends, and colleagues.
The reporters have been detained since December 12, 2017 and if found guilty, are facing up to 14 years in prison.

item.title: Federal judge extends deadline to reunite immigrant children with parents
item.dc:creator: lmoffutt
item.content:encoded:
The US District Court for the Southern District of California [official website] on Monday extended [order, PDF] the deadline for US attorneys to reunite 102 immigrant children with their families. Under a June 26 order granting [JURIST report] the plaintiffs' preliminary injunction, US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) [official website] was to reunite children under five years old with their families by Monday, and minor children over five by July 25. ICE requested [text, PDF] an extension for the deadline last Thursday, reasoning that the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) [official website] requires additional time to fulfill its statutory obligations while reuniting the children with their families. ICE also sought clarification concerning whether HHS was expected to uphold its statutory obligations, saying:
The processes that HHS has developed in order to fulfill its statutory obligations are critical to protecting children against the well-documented risk of trafficking or abuse, but they also require HHS to follow procedures that are time-consuming, even in this unique context. Defendants thus seek confirmation about the Court’s intent in its order as it relates to those procedures and, as appropriate, relief from the Court’s deadlines.
Judge Dana M. Sabraw ordered [text, PDF] that the ICE provide the plaintiffs with a list of the 101 children seeking reunification, along with an update on the child's reunification status. Secondly, she ordered the ICE to provide a timeline for reunification. The timeline must state whether each child will be reunited by the deadline. Sabraw further stated that the ICE must provide an acceptable excuse for those children who will not be reunited by the deadline. The excuse must be "legitimate logistical impediments that render timely compliance impossible or excusable, e.g., detention of the Class Member in criminal custody or removal of the Class Member from the United States."
item.category: US District Court for the Southern District of California

item.title: Trump nominates Kavanaugh to US Supreme Court
item.dc:creator: lmoffutt
item.content:encoded: US President Donald Trump on Monday nominated [press release] Brett M. Kavanaugh of the US Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit [official website] to the US Supreme Court to replace Justice Anthony Kennedy, who will retire [JURIST report] on July 31st.  Kennedy was nominated [JURIST op-ed] in 1987 by then-president Ronald Reagan. He was seen as having a relatively  neutral ideology and methodology of interpretation. Throughout his time on the court, Kennedy often acted as the swing vote [JURIST report] among four conservative and four liberal justices. Kavanaugh [official profile], on the other hand, is believed to represent a strong conservative ideology and perspective. Trump introduced [text, HTML] Kavanaugh as "a brilliant jurist, with a clear and effective writing style, universally regarded as one of the finest and sharpest legal minds of our time," with "impeccable credentials, unsurpassed qualifications, and a proven commitment to equal justice under the law." Trump prefaced his announcement with a brief word about Kennedy's and the late Justice Antonin Scalia's time on the Court. He went on to say that he believes Kavanaugh will use a similar methodology to uphold the Constitution.

item.title: Trump pardons Oregon ranchers whose arrest lead to standoff
item.dc:creator: emccarthy
item.content:encoded: US President Donald Trump granted two full presidential pardons [White House press release] Tuesday to Dwight Lincoln Hammond, Jr., and his son, Steven Hammond, cattle ranchers in Oregon who were serving 5-year sentences for arson on federal land. It was this sentencing that set off a 41-day armed occupation of Oregon’s Malheur National Wildlife Refuge [official website] in 2016. While the two were acquitted on most charges regarding the incident, Dwight Lincoln Hammond, Jr. had served three years of a five-year sentence. Steven Hammond was on his fourth year. "The Hammonds are devoted family men, respected contributors to their local community, and have widespread support from their neighbors, local law enforcement, and farmers and ranchers across the West. Justice is overdue for Dwight and Steven Hammond, both of whom are entirely deserving of these Grants of Executive Clemency," said a White House statement. In October 2016, a jury in Portland acquitted [JURIST report] all seven defendants involved in the 41-day occupation, in a trial that lasted nearly six weeks. The Executive Grants of Clemency, full pardons of the Hammonds add to a number of Presidential pardons since Trump took office, some stirring controversy — including a posthumous pardon of Jack Johnson [JURIST report], the first black heavyweight champion, former Arizona Sherriff Joe Arpaio [JURIST report], and Scooter Libby [NYT Report].

item.title: Third Circuit upholds New Jersey bail system
item.dc:creator: whibbitts
item.content:encoded:
The US Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit [official website] upheld [opinion, PDF] Monday a US District Court ruling that New Jersey's new bail system, which does away with most cash bail, is constitutional. The law was challenged by Brittan Holland, who was arrested for aggravated assault last year. He alleged that the new system created by the New Jersey Criminal Justice Reform Act [text] was unconstitutional because it violated the Fourth Amendment, Eighth Amendment, and the due process clause [text] of the Fourteenth Amendment of the US Constitution. The opinion, written by Judge Thomas L. Ambro noted that:
We find no right to these forms of monetary bail in the Eighth Amendment’s proscription of excessive bail nor in the Fourteenth Amendment’s substantive and procedural due process components. We also reject Holland’s “less intrusive means” theory of a Fourth Amendment violation, and so we hold he has not made a sufficient showing of a violation of that constitutional amendment. Without a constitutional right violated, and with reconsideration of current release conditions an option if circumstances suggest and a request made, irreparable harm does not exist.
The courts ruling comes in the middle of a controversy surrounding the cash bail system. This system, used in many states, was criticized [JURIST report] by the UN Special Rapporteur on Extreme Poverty and Human Rights for criminalizing those who do not have the funds to pay monetary bail. In April, the American Civil Liberties Union sued [JURIST report] a Texas county after it says the county jailed many defendants for being unable to afford the bail without a "meaningful hearing."
